Executive Summary of Risk Management Plan

Dry Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant







1.  The city of Nashville's Department of Water and Sewerage Services (Metro Water Services) Risk Management Plan is a combination of technology, procedures, training and management.  Each element of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management program is addressed.  The approach is to prepare a plan tailored for each facility to increase knowledge, prevent accidents, and to respond to emergencies.



2.  The Dry Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant has been in existence in its current location almost fifty-eight (58) years.  The plant is currently rated to treat an average daily flow of 24 million gallons per day and a maximum wet weather flow of 63 million gallons of wastewater each day.  It has undergone expansion four (4) times, the last of which was completed in 2008.  The facility is located in the north section of Nashville and encompasses approximately 25 acres.  The purpose is to treat the sewage from Madison, Goodlettsville, Hendersonville, Old Hickory and Millersville.  The water received at the plant as sewage is treated to remove the contaminants by a multi-step process known as activated sludge treatment.  The material removed from the water is called sludge or biosolids.  Each month the plant disposes of approximately 360 dry tons of biosolids.   The clean, clear water is then returned to the Cumberland River.  The final phase of treatment is chlorination, to disinfect the water and dechlorination to reduce the impact of the chlorine on the Cumberland.  The chlorine facility includes piping, valves, pressure gauges, evaporators, and chlorinators for chlorine.  It also has piping, valves, pressure gauges, evaporators, and  sulfinators for the declorination agent (sulfur dioxide).  Both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are hazardous because they are respiratory irritants when inhaled.  Liquid chlorine and sulfur dioxide are stored and used from one-ton cylinders.

Usually, fifteen cylinders of chlorine and fifteen cylinders of sulfur dioxide are on site.  The amount of chemicals used varies with the plant flow and its characteristics.  The quantity used is normally in the range a few hundred to 1000 pounds of each per day.  The chlorine facility is normally unmanned, however; it is monitored remotely from the plant control room.  The plant is manned 24 hours a day, seven days a week and the operators visit the chlorine site at various times during the day.  Various types of safety equipment, alarms, sensors, and monitors are in place at this facility.     



3.  Off site consequence analysis has been completed for each chemical.  Both the worst case and alternative release scenarios have been calculated using RMP comp. Details of the analysis can be found in the Department of Metro Water Services Dry Creek WWTP RMP documentation.

 



4.   The accident release prevention program for the Dry Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant includes the following:



a) Extensive operator training.

b) Preventive Maintenance Program for the chlorine equipment.

c) Use of state of the art process and safety equipment.

d) Use of specific operating procedures written and reviewed by plant personnel.

e) Scheduled performance reviews for hazards in the procedures and equipment.

f) Implementation of a compliance inspection program.

 

 Presently, specific accident prevention measures include the following:

 

a) The site is near the control room and is monitored from the control room by the Distributed Control System (DCS).

b) Electronic leak detectors are in place to provide audible and graphic alarms in the control room and on site. Chemical feed stops if a leak develops in the vacuum systems.

c) Self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) are available in the event of leaks and for personnel protection during connection/disconnection.

d) Leak repair "B" kits with both chlorine and sulfur dioxide gaskets are on site at the facility. 

e)

The building is marked with universal fire code hazard symbols.



5.  No off site accidental releases have occurred at this plant in the last five (5) years.



6.  The plant falls under the community emergency response plan and the Nashville Fire Department is aware of the possible hazards.  Metro Water Services and the Nashville Fire Department are members of the Local Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC).  The program includes a response decision flow chart and a notification plan.  Plant personnel investigate and repair minor leaks while the Fire Department responds in the event of a release.



7. MWS piloted peracetic acid and has elected not to switch to this system.  In lieu of peracetic acid or liquid hypochlorite, MWS has acquired an engineering firm that has designed a UV disinfection system to replace the gaseous chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  This project will be constructed within the next 2-5 years.
